There is other fellowship money I haven't added on year. Since I haven't *officially* signed paperwork on that, I haven't added that to the calculation. That should be an extra ~$5,000. I'm being *very* conservative with my estimates here.

WRITING.TITLE: Signed my first-ever lease - need general planning advice!
WRITING.TEXT:
Hi r/personalfinance, I'm u/subject4588!
I'm a 23 year-old graduate student on the west coast. I just signed a lease for my own apartment at $1525 monthly without factoring into electricity, gas, and internet. It's not the cheapest option out there, but I have had shitty experiences with roommates and I would honestly rather pay extra for living alone. Also, the place is a 3-minute walk to my campus building; this meant I could not pass it up (housing goes fast in a college town!).
Though I don't have any substantive reason to worry, I still am concerned about how I am going to live a cost-effective life (food, discretionary, transportation). I'll be making ~28,000 annually. I've never paid this much in rent and never had to *really* live by myself, but people whom I trust tell me that living alone is worth it. And for it to be true in my case, it must be sustainable.
Thanks in advance!
EDIT: To add that if there is more context that is necessary, I will provide it.

I just saw a commenter who insinuated that this was clearly a joke. I would counter that it isn't so clear. As a black man in academia as well, I can relate to showing *no sign* that the white person I'm talking with just said something clearly racist to me. If my experience can serve as a guide, Dr. Hill might be internally going through something completely opposite to what we see him saying.

WRITING.TEXT: A man got to have a code.

Accepting that it is normal to have anxiety, to seek help for it, and to cut people off who do not value me as a person and/or put me down. I also have accepted that I don't have to be everyone's friend every time, since part of why my self-esteem was so low/fragile was because I was always seeking positive attention at all times, and would feel down if I didn't get it.

WRITING.TITLE: No one would, after one date, move in with the other person. But that's effectively what we do when looking for roommates.

WRITING.TEXT: There's a reason why the best shooters are called Marxmen

I have two dates that vie for the title.
**Date One** I went to a date at a Peruvian restaurant in Jamaica, Queens (coming from Harlem so it was a trip). I dressed to the nines, and I also shaved. I arrived a bit earlier than she did. When she finally got there, the first thing she said was "Oh my god! You're [subject4588]! You look fifteen!" I replied, "You look single", and I walked out.
**Date Two** This was a couple of months ago, in San Francisco. This date had actually been going well, until we got to my immigrant history. She asked me what language I spoke at home, and I said Swahili. Without missing a beat she asked: "Is that the one with the clicks in it?"
I have now taken a vow of monastic celibacy.
